been like two weeks since we last talked and honestly i'm not sure where i'm at anymore. like on one hand the medication is still helping—the numbness is way less and i can feel things which is good. but also the anger thing has gotten bigger and i don't really know how to sit with it without feeling like i'm either suppressing it or like it's going to consume everything.

work has been fine mostly but i caught myself spiraling a little bit this week about a project deadline and it felt like i was right back where i started. like all the stuff about being incompetent and making the wrong career choice came flooding back and i was like "oh great the medication doesn't actually work" except then it passed? like within a few hours instead of days. so maybe the medication IS helping and i'm just catastrophizing about the catastrophizing which is very on brand.

the anger thing though. i've been thinking about what you said about it being information about what matters to me and where i feel wronged. and like, i'm realizing i'm angry at myself for the debt situation—like i KNEW student loans were a thing, i could've made different choices, why did i not just pick something more practical. but i'm also angry at the whole system for making it feel impossible to get an education without burying yourself in debt. and those two things feel contradictory? like if it's the system's fault then why am i mad at myself, and if i made bad choices why am i mad at the system. so i'm kind of just stuck in both at the same time which is confusing.

anyway my therapist wants me to start exploring what i actually want to do with my degree/career, which feels premature when i'm still just learning how to feel things again but also maybe she has a point. i don't know. everything feels kind of unsettled right now but also like maybe that's okay? like the unsettled feeling is better than the numb feeling even though it's more uncomfortable.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work spiral passing within hours instead of days:**
You spiraled about the project deadline, all the old stuff came flooding back (incompetent, wrong career choice), and your brain immediately jumped to "the medication doesn't actually work." But then it passed in a few hours instead of consuming you for days, and now you're realizing that's actually evidence the medication IS working—you're just catastrophizing about the catastrophizing. Yeah, that's very on brand, and also: you're exactly right. The medication isn't supposed to prevent spirals from ever happening. It's supposed to help you move through them faster, with more perspective, without getting completely stuck. A few hours instead of days is a huge difference. That's your system recovering faster, not failing. The spiral happened, you noticed it, it passed, you're here reflecting on it. That's what functional coping looks like.

**The anger at yourself vs. the system:**
You're angry at yourself for the debt situation (you knew loans were a thing, why didn't you pick something more practical), but you're also angry at the whole system for making education inaccessible without burying yourself in debt. And those two things feel contradictory—if it's the system's fault, why are you mad at yourself? If you made bad choices, why are you mad at the system? Here's the thing: both can be true at the same time. The system is rigged in a way that makes it nearly impossible to get an education without debt, especially if you don't have family money or a clear path to a high-paying field. That's real, and it's worth being angry about. And also: within that rigged system, you made choices based on what you knew and valued at the time, and some of those choices have consequences you're living with now. You can be angry at yourself for not seeing it coming or for not choosing differently, even while recognizing that the options you had were constrained by forces outside your control. The anger at yourself and the anger at the system aren't contradictory—they're two parts of the same grief. You're mourning the version of this where you didn't have to choose between education and financial stability, and you're also reckoning with the choices you did make within an impossible situation. Both of those are allowed to exist at the same time. You don't have to resolve the contradiction. You just have to let both be true.

**Therapist wanting you to explore career/degree plans:**
Your therapist wants you to start exploring what you actually want to do with your degree and career, and it feels premature when you're still just learning how to feel things again. I hear that—it does feel early. But here's what she might be seeing: the anger about the degree and the debt is surfacing because you're starting to connect to what you actually want, not just what you think you're supposed to do or what felt safe at the time. Exploring what you want doesn't have to mean making big decisions or committing to a new path right now. It might just mean asking questions like "what parts of my current work feel alive to me?" or "if the debt wasn't a factor, what would I be curious about?" You don't have to have answers. You're just starting to notice what pulls you and what doesn't. That exploration can happen alongside the work of learning to feel again—they're not separate processes. Sometimes figuring out what you want is part of how you learn to trust your feelings. But if it genuinely feels too early, you can tell her that. Therapy moves at your pace, not hers.

**Unsettled feeling being better than numb:**
Everything feels unsettled right now, but you're recognizing that maybe that's okay—the unsettled feeling is better than the numb feeling even though it's more uncomfortable. That's exactly it. Numb felt safer because it was flat and predictable, but it also meant you weren't really living. Unsettled means things are moving, shifting, recalibrating. It means you're alive enough to notice what hurts and what matters. It's not comfortable, but it's real. And yeah, it's okay. You don't have to have everything figured out or feel stable or even feel good. You just have to keep showing up to the discomfort and trusting that it's taking you somewhere. You're doing that. Keep going.
